Sheriff Kyle Bourgault added in a statement that his "deputies handled the situation professionally and without injury to anyone involved."
“But the larger issue is not the resistance we encountered — it is the battle Mr. Martin himself is facing," he said. "Addiction is a disease, and it requires both accountability and empathy.”
Bourgault added, “My hope is that Mr. Martin receives the resources and support he needs to overcome this struggle and continue to share his gift of music with fans in a healthier way.”

Martin is currently in the middle of his “Years In The Making Tour.” He had a show scheduled on Aug. 30 in Norway, Maine, and according to his website, he has upcoming concerts in Montgomery, Indiana, on Sept. 5 and Saginaw, Michigan, on Sept. 6.

title: Who Is Leaving ‘SNL’? What Departing Cast Members Have Said
summary: “Saturday Night Live” returns for Season 51 in October. Here's a running list of all the cast members who will not be returning after the landmark 50th season.
story: “Saturday Night Live” returns for its 51st season in just over a month, but without some key players.
After the longstanding NBC sketch comedy show celebrated 50 years on air — commemorated by a three-hour long anniversary special — “SNL” is seeing some changes.
Over the course of the past week, a number of cast members have announced their departure from the show.
While an official “SNL” cast has yet to be announced for Season 51, creator Lorne Michaels confirmed in an August interview with Puck News that he plans to “shake things up” around the show.
“SNL” Season 51 premieres Saturday, Oct. 4, on NBC.
Here’s a list of who is leaving “SNL” and what they've said about their departure.
Who Is Leaving ‘SNL’?
After eight seasons with the show, Heidi Gardner will not be returning to “SNL” for Season 51, TODAY.com confirmed.
The comedian, who made her “SNL” debut in 2017, has not commented on her departure.
Michael Longfellow, who made his “SNL” debut in 2022, confirmed Aug. 28 that he will not be returning for the show’s 51st season.

In an Instagram post, Longfellow shared a compilation of photos from the live comedy show, writing, “Will not be returning for a 4th season at SNL. Wish I was but, so it goes. It was the best three years of my life so far.”
“I feel nothing but gratitude for the experience and everyone there,” he wrote.
Addressing Michaels, Longfellow told the show creator that he “gave me the greatest job in the world and changed my life,” adding that he “even put my mom on TV.”
“Thank you doesnt begin to cover it, but thank you,” he continued. “I’ll miss it all, but I’ll miss the friends I made and seeing them everyday the most.”
Though he didn’t announce specific plans, Longfellow added that he’s “excited for the future and things to come,” before referring to several inside “SNL” jokes.
Following a three-year run on “SNL,” Walker announced his departure from the show in an Instagram post Aug. 25, writing, “me and baby broke up.”
After a screenshot of a text he appears to have sent reading, “I’m out,” with a partying emoji, he shared a longer message.

“To me, jobs in this industry feel like a bunch of little marriages. Some of ‘em last for a long time if we’re lucky, but most of them are fleeting. Permanent until they’re not. That’s the deal. You know what it is when you sign up," he began.
In his message, Walker, who joined the show in 2022, described his time on the show with, "sometimes it was really cool. Sometimes it was toxic as hell."
"But we did what we made the most of what it was, even amidst all the dysfunction. We made a f----- up lil family," he continued.
As for what’s next, Walker shared he had plans to go to Japan and is “tryna be in a prestige drama” when he returns.
Walker then took to X to address a fan’s post about him and Longfellow leaving “SNL.”
"yall acting like we died lol we just getting different jobs," he wrote.

When asked whether he left the show on his own accord during an interview with Rolling Stone published Aug. 30, Walker once again referred to his experience with “SNL” as a relationship. The comedian said that he and the show “decided together that it was time to go our separate ways.”
“I think I felt ready to leave the show, and I think the show felt ready to leave me,” he continued. “I was just ready to do something else. We both felt like it was time.”
Walker explained that “SNL” posed both a “big time commitment and life commitment.”

“There’s been a lot of life stuff that I feel like I’ve had to miss out on,” he added. “And I felt ready to do a different version of my life. I think that me and the show are both ready to turn the page.”
Wakim, who spent one season as a featured player, announced Aug. 27 that he will not be returning to “SNL.”
The comedian penned a lengthy message on Instagram about leaving the show, writing, “it was a gut punch of a call to get but i’m so grateful for my time there.”
He described signing into 30 Rockefeller Plaza, where "SNL" is filmed, thinking, "how insane it is to get to work there."
"it was the most terrifying, thrilling, and rewarding experience of my life and i will miss it dearly and all the brilliant people that work there that made it feel like a home," Wakim wrote.
He then thanked Michaels "for taking a chance on me and changing my life" when he was cast in Season 50.
“i was so lucky to bring some of myself in there and say things i believed in and i’m excited for whatever chapter comes next. here’s to making more art without compromise,” he concluded.

title: See How TODAY Covered Princess Diana's Funeral 28 Years Ago
summary: On the 28th anniversary of Princess Diana's death, TODAY looks back at how the show covered the late royal's funeral in 1997.
story: It's been nearly 30 years since Princess Diana died.
The former Princess of Wales died from injuries she sustained in a car accident in Paris on Aug. 31, 1997.
Fleeing from photographers, driver Henri Paul lost control of the Mercedes-Benz and crashed into a pillar inside the Pont de l'Alma tunnel.
Diana and her boyfriend, Dodi Fayed, died, as did Paul. The only person who survived the crash was bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones.

Diana, who is survived by her two kids — Prince William, 43, and Prince Harry, 40 — received a grand funeral at Westminster Abbey. The emotional farewell on Sept. 6, 1997, was witnessed by billions worldwide, per the BBC. The Guardian also reported that a crowd of “a million and more” lined the route to Westminster Abbey.
TODAY previewed the funeral on Sept. 5, 1997. Former NBC News reporter Keith Miller interviewed British author Robert Fox about what to expect for the grim day.

“We’re going to get a clash between the mystery of monarchy, something which is above the law and above men and slightly below God and the angels, and what Britain has always passed on to the world as democracy,” he said. “And it’s going to be a very, very potent cocktail indeed.”
Fox also talked about the importance of the Abbey and said it was “very interesting” that Diana’s funeral would occur there.
“That is quite outstanding,” he said.

The royal church has hosted many events through the years, such as the coronation and funeral of Queen Elizabeth II and the coronation of her son King Charles III. Diana's parents, John Spencer and Frances Shand Kydd, got married there as well.
“The first sight will be very, very grand, a soaring nave, a nave where kings and queens have met, have married, and have been carried to their graves,” Fox said.

After the funeral, Diana was laid to rest on a small island in the middle of an ornamental lake in Althorp, the stately Northamptonshire home of the Spencer family. Her gravesite is not accessible by the public.
On Aug. 31, 2025, Diana's brother, Charles Spencer, shared a picture of him visiting his late sister's memorial on Instagram.
"Flowers we cut this morning from Althorp’s gardens for the Island," he said in the caption. "Always an impossible day."

title: Former 'Degrassi' Star Miriam McDonald Responds to Comments About Different Appearance in New Doc
summary: Former “Degrassi” star Miriam McDonald has spoken out on social media amid criticism over her appearance in the trailer for the upcoming documentary, “Degrassi: Whatever It Takes.”McDonald, who portrayed Emma Nelson in “Degrassi: The Next Generation,” the fourth series of the “Degrassi” franchise, is one of the former stars of the long-running Canadian teen drama featured in the new documentary premiering at the Toronto International Film Festival Sept. 13.
story: Former “Degrassi” star Miriam McDonald has spoken out on social media amid criticism over her appearance in the trailer for the upcoming documentary, “Degrassi: Whatever It Takes.”

McDonald, who portrayed Emma Nelson in “Degrassi: The Next Generation,” the fourth series of the “Degrassi” franchise, is one of the former stars of the long-running Canadian teen drama featured in the new documentary premiering at the Toronto International Film Festival Sept. 13.
Amid excitement from fans about the doc, some social media users called out McDonald’s appearance, with one comment on the trailer reading, “What the heck did Emma do to her face!!!”
McDonald took the opportunity to address the comments about her appearance in an Aug. 27 Instagram post.

“When I watched the documentary back, I didn’t feel good about how I looked,” she admitted in the caption. “About a month or two before filming (which was almost two years ago now), I had Botox and filler done. Looking back, I regret that choice.”
McDonald said she “wasn’t feeling ‘perfect’” and saw “little things” she wanted to fix. While she thought the procedures would help her, they made her look “less like myself.”
She said that she didn't think anybody would notice the procedures and clarified that she hadn’t experienced “a medical issue or complication,” but rather “a lapse in judgment.”
“Thankfully, Botox wears off and fillers dissolve over time,” she continued. “But interviews live forever online, and that version of me is now out there to stay.”
McDonald said the comments did “sting,” adding, “I may have once been an actress, but I don’t live in that world anymore. I don’t have a thick Hollywood skin—I’m just a person.”
“And the truth is, hearing critiques about how I look hurts just as much as it would hurt your sister, your daughter, or your friend,” she wrote.
McDonald continued her message in the comment section of the post, reflecting on her experience growing up on camera.
The actor, now 38, was a teenager during most of her time on the show, starring in a main role for nine seasons from 2001 to 2010.
She said that being a young actor “meant my most awkward phases were captured for the world to see, and that scrutiny has stayed with me into adulthood.”

“Ironically, the very things I tried to ‘fix’ with Botox and filler only magnified what I was insecure about,” she added. “I’m embarrassed to admit that in an era of ‘self-love,’ I didn’t have much of it for myself in that moment.”
McDonald highlighted the lessons that she learned from the experience, telling fans, “I’d rather embrace my frown lines than look like I’ve had ‘too much Botox.’”

“I’m still a work in progress, but I’m learning, and I’m grateful,” she said. “If my experience serves as a cautionary tale, then I’m glad to share it. Or, if it simply reminds someone that perfection isn’t found in changing ourselves but in owning who we are—then it was worth writing this.”

The actor received a flurry of support in the comment section of her post, including from former co-star Lauren Collins, who portrayed Paige Michalchuk in the fourth installment of the franchise alongside McDonald.
“Still the same brave, intelligent girl I knew all those years ago,” she wrote. “Unafraid to be vulnerable, beautiful inside and out.”
McDonald also acknowledged the kind responses she received in an Instagram story shared to her highlights, thanking fans “for the grace and support” shown.

“Vulnerability isn’t easy, but in a world often ruled by optics, choosing honesty feels like the best path forward,” she wrote. “We’re all carrying battles unseen, and kindness makes the weight lighter for everyone.”
McDonald said that it was “scary” to be vulnerable but said the support she's received “has been such a relief”
“My only goal in this space is to share with authenticity, to uplift, and the stay clear of the parts of social media that can pull us down,” she said.

The trailer for “Degrassi: Whatever It Takes” featured several former cast members on the series, including Drake, who played Jimmy Brooks for six seasons on “Degrassi: The Next Generation” and famously threatened legal action to change his character’s storyline.

The “Degrassi” franchise, which includes three movies, dates back to 1979 with “The Kids of Degrassi Street.” The show spawned subsequent series including “Degrassi Junior High,” “Degrassi High,” “Degrassi: The Next Generation” and “Degrassi: Next Class,” which concluded in 2017.

title: Lil Nas X's Dad Details His Tearful Conversation With Son in Jail After His Arrest
summary: Lil Nas X’s father has spoken out after his son's recent arrest
story: Lil Nas X’s father has spoken out after his son's recent arrest.
The two-time Grammy-winning musician, who legal name is Montero Lamar Hill, was arrested and taken to a hospital on Aug. 21 in Los Angeles.
The arrest came after he was found walking on the street without clothes and charged at officers. He was subsequently charged with four felonies after allegedly injuring officers amid the arrest.
Lil Nas X briefly addressed the incident on social media, sharing a video on his Instagram story Aug. 26, telling his fans that he was “gonna be OK,” per NBC News.
The musician’s father, Robert Stafford, also addressed his son’s recent arrest in an Aug. 29 interview with The Sunday Times.

During the interview, he cited the pressure his son was under to continue to achieve the same level of success in his career, having to provide for his family and his fears about his mother's struggle with addiction.
“I understand how the music business is,” Stafford told the publication. “It’s like a high. When you get to that level, you want that drug again, you want to hit that high again.”

He added, “For a 26-year-old to have to deal with what he’s dealing with — to be a breadwinner for a lot of people, the inability to change his mother’s situation and the pressure he puts on himself…”
Stafford said that he was able to visit his son in jail, but when he walked through the door, he “couldn’t do anything but cry.”

“To see my baby boy on the other side of that glass. We shed tears with each other for a minute,” Stafford added. “And I had to tell him that ‘what you’re going through is normal’. We all have breakdowns every now and then, but the difference is, yours get played out in the public eye.”

Stafford also provided his son’s point of view on the situation, sharing, “When I went to visit he asked me to say, ‘tell everybody I’m sorry they saw me like that’. Even in that moment, he was apologizing to people for something he was going through.”
Despite what his son has experienced, Stafford expressed optimism over Lil Nas X’s future.
“Hopefully, this is a turning point in his mental stability,” Stafford said. “Sometimes God will take you through your worst moment to give you your best moment.”
In a statement to NBC News, the Los Angeles Police Department said that officers responded to reports of a nude man just before 6 a.m. and that the man had charged at the officers when they arrived.
A law enforcement source confirmed to NBC News that the man was Lil Nas X, sharing that the musician had punched an officer twice in the face during the incident.
Lil Nas X has pleaded not guilty to the four felony charges.
In his brief address to fans on Aug. 26, he said, “That was terrifying, that was terrifying, that was a terrifying last four days. But your girl’s gonna be all right.”
CORRECTION: (Aug. 31, 2025, 11:37 a.m. ET): An earlier version of this article said Lil Nas X was in prison. He was in jail. This has since been corrected.)

title: EXCLUSIVE: Bad Bunny Reacts to Jon Hamm Dancing at Puerto Rico Residency
summary: On "Sunday Sitdown with Willie Geist," Bad Bunny recalled the time Jon Hamm attended his Puerto Rico residency and was seen dancing and singing in the crowd.
story: Bad Bunny is weighing in on Jon Hamm's unwavering support of his music.
Earlier this month, the "Mad Men" actor was seen dancing and singing along to Bad Bunny's music at the rapper's concert residency in Puerto Rico, “No Me Quiero Ir de Aquí."

In one video shared by TODAY’s Executive Editor, Arianna Davis, Hamm could be seen having the time of his life as he vibed out to Bad Bunny's music while wearing a black-and-white printed shirt, a bucket hat and a pair of matching shorts.

While recalling that moment on the Aug. 31 episode of "Sunday Sitdown," Bad Bunny told host Willie Geist that he's glad that Hamm was able to let loose at his concert, which took place at the José Miguel Agrelot Coliseum in San Juan.
"I saw him there on the casita probably, he was lit," Bad Bunny laughed. "I’m happy that he went and he had fun."
Bad Bunny started his Puerto Rico residency in July, and so far, many celebrities have come to see him perform, such as LeBron James, Ricky Martin and Austin Butler.

"This is so far my best experience in music, maybe in life. What is happening right now in San Juan in that arena is something magical," he said. "It’s such a pleasure to show my culture, my country, my land, right there in my house. Like, be with my family every night, sleep at home every night. That’s beautiful. I don’t have to take planes."

Bad Bunny's residency has become so popular that hundreds and thousands of tourists have already descended onto the island to see him perform, generating more than $200 million to help the island's economy.
"We show the best of Puerto Rico, and also the toughest or delicate things about Puerto Rico," he shared. "And I think that’s the beauty of this show. That it’s very powerful and honest."
Bad Bunny, who grew up just outside of San Juan, admits he's come a long way in his career. He's gone from singing in his church choir to now selling out shows in his home country.
When he walks on stage to a sold out crowd, he says he can't help but think about the little boy he once was, who dreamed of being a musician.

"That’s the beautiful thing. Like, enjoy what I’m doing now, but never forget where that dream start," he said. "Put your energy into something that you really want to and give your best. That is what life is about, to me."

title: How New Sphere Show Alters ‘The Wizard of Oz’ — and Aims to Bring the Classic to Life
summary: "The Wizard of Oz" is playing at Las Vegas' Sphere with several notable changes to the film.
story: Dorothy, Scarecrow, Tin Man and the Cowardly Lion walked down the yellow brick road to Oz 86 years ago. Now, “The Wizard of Oz” fans can feel like they’re joining them.
The Sphere in Las Vegas is bringing the film to life, with a reimagined version of the 1939 classic based on L. Frank Baum’s “The Wonderful Wizard of Oz.”
During the experience, which opened Aug. 28, “The Wizard of Oz” is projected onto the Sphere’s 160,000 square-foot display, immersing the audience in nearly 360-degree visuals and sound.
Here’s what to know about the show.
Immersive Features
“The Wizard of Oz” fans will feel like they’re stepping into the eye of a Kansas tornado when watching the movie at the Sphere.
Due to the wraparound visuals, the Sphere says the audience will feel “blown away” during the scene in which Dorothy is transported from Kansas to Oz via cyclone.
NBC News’ Gadi Schwartz attended the experience reporting for TODAY and witnessed debris flying around the theater to bring to life the “monstrous tornado” from the film.

The audience is also engrossed in multi-sensory 4D elements during the film, including “high-velocity wind arrays, atmospheric fog, towering fire bursts, bubbles, and infrasound haptic seats," according to the Sphere's website.
During one scene, in which Dorothy, Scarecrow, Tin Man and the Lion are being swarmed by flying winged monkeys, the audience appears to experience digitized versions of the creatures flying overhead.
The Sphere even took the experience outside the physical venue — and up to the Las Vegas sky.
Mimicking the Wicked Witch of the West writing a message to Dorothy using smoke in the sky, the Sphere shared an image of the line “SURRENDER DOROTHY...OR DIE” penned in puffs over the venue.
Changes to ‘The Wizard of Oz’
The Sphere experience also made some notable changes to play the film on its wraparound screen.
First, the runtime. While "The Wizard of Oz" typically clocks in at around 102 minutes, the runtime for the Sphere show is 75 minutes.

Then, there's the score. While the audience will hear Judy Garland’s original vocals as Dorothy, the Sphere’s version includes a re-recorded rendition of the original movie score for “new clarity.” Sphere Studios separated the vocals from the instrumentals in the original tracks and used an orchestra to record a more detailed variation of the score, according to a video on the venue's official YouTube page.
According to the Sphere, the new score transforms the original versions of songs like “Over the Rainbow” into music better fit for the venue’s 167,000 programmable speakers built into the seats.
“You can actually feel the voice and effects,” Carolyn Blackwood, head of Sphere Studios, said in the video. “And with the 4D, you feel like you’re there.”
The experience’s producer, Jane Rosenthal, said in a video that their goal is to “maintain the integrity of the original filmmakers’ intent.”
“It’s part of our cultural history,” Rosenthal added. “You can’t just take it and do anything with it.”

The film was originally shot in a 4:3 aspect ratio, but the Sphere's screen is not a flat rectangle. To adapt the classic film, the team used artificial intelligence to make it fit the massive display and improve the resolution. Visual effects specialists took the original sets and “extended them realistically beyond that based on the production design,” producer and CEO of software design company Magnopus Ben Grossmann said in a video about the experience.
He explained that, working with a team at Google, they broke down the original “Wizard of Oz” frame by frame using super resolution, pinpointing how to enhance the 1930s shots.

For example, several shots solely show a character from their waist to the top of their head. The team used character outpainting to restore the shots and transform into the large displays for the Sphere.

Similarly, some of the original closeup shots with minimal background details are now wider shots, meaning they must show more of the set and additional characters. The team used "performance generation" technology to illustrate what characters could have been doing in the background.
The use of AI for the project has come with some controversy. Some described the alteration of the original work as an offense to cinema.
“honestly this is the ugliest and most dishonorable thing to happen to classic cinema in years,” one social media user said on X.

A recent Variety review of the showing called the effects, “creepy, applied over existing footage in a way that clearly interferes with the humanity of the underlying performances — that is, if there was an underlying performance to begin with.”
USA Today, however, dubbed the show "nothing short of extraordinary."

On the Sphere’s website, the venue details how it uses AI and said, “Through ‘The Wizard of Oz’ at Sphere, Sphere is leading the way in applying AI and visual effects to bring new creative possibilities to the entertainment industry, and wonder to the world.”
How Much Are Tickets to 'The Wizard of Oz' at the Sphere?
Depending on seating, tickets for the film range in price from about $109 to $149.
There are also two VIP packages available: the Good Witch Premium Experience and the Bad Witch Ultimate VIP Experience.

The Good Witch experience — which includes expedited entry, a food and beverage credit and premium seating — costs about $320. The Bad Witch experience includes everything from the Good Witch package in addition to pre-show lounge access and a poster, and costs about $370.

title: Emma Heming Willis Responds to 'Judgment' of How She's Caring for Husband Bruce Willis
summary: Bruce Willis' wife, Emma Heming Willis, shared a video message for anyone who "unfairly" judges caregivers on social media.
story: Bruce Willis' wife, Emma Heming Willis, has a message for anyone who "unfairly" judges caregivers without knowing what they're going through.

In an Instagram video, Heming Willis said she been receiving backlash after opening up about her experience caring for her husband amid his frontotemporal dementia diagnosis, which the family announced in February 2023.

“What I knew is that by sharing some of our intimate information that we would see these two camps right? It would be people with an opinion versus people with an actual experience,” she said. “And it’s been a perfect example to see in the comments section.”

In an ABC News special with Diane Sawyer that aired in August, Heming Willis spoke about FTD, a neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects communication and behavior, and shared that she and Willis live separately so he can have constant care.

Heming Willis, who has been married to the "Die Hard" actor since 2009, said in her latest Instagram video that she wanted to give the interview "a couple days to sort of land and breathe" and praised the special for raising awareness of FTD.
But Heming Willis said she noticed some social media users giving their opinions on how she is caring for her husband.
"That is what caregivers are up against — judgment from others and criticism from others," she said.
The former journalist then read a quote from her upcoming book, "The Unexpected Journey: Finding Strength, Hope and Yourself on the Caregiving Path."

"Everyone will have an opinion, but you have to remind yourself that most don't have the experience to back it up," she read. "And if that's the case, they shouldn't offer their two cents about it, and you shouldn't pay them any mind."
"Even if someone is closely familiar with dementia or the condition you are caring for, they aren't in your home, so they don't know how your person is behaving or your family dynamics," she added.
In the caption, Heming Willis talked more about the difficulties that caregivers go through.

"Too often, caregivers are judged quickly and unfairly by those who haven’t lived this journey or stood on the front lines of it," she wrote. "Sharing openly may invite opinions, but more importantly, it creates connection and validation for those actually navigating the realities of caregiving every day."

Willis has five daughters: Rumer, Scout and Tallulah — whom he shares with ex-wife Demi Moore— and Mabel and Evelyn, whom he welcomed with Heming Willis. The blended family often spends time together for holidays and birthdays.
Tallulah commented on Heming Willis' post, "I love you so much. We love you so much. Thank you for all you do for us and our family."
Maria Shriver added, "Well said carry on this book will help so many you sharing your experience will help so many we are here to help others job well done proud of," with a red heart emoji.
In the ABC special, Heming Willis gave a health update about her husband.
“Bruce is still very mobile. Bruce is in really great health overall, it’s just his brain that is failing him,” Heming Willis said.
She said his "language is going" but added the family has learned to adapt.
“We have a way of communicating with him, which is just a different way," Heming Willis said.

title: 'Thursday Murder Club' Ending: All the Murders, Solved
summary: Read on for an ending explainer for Netflix's "Thursday Murder Club" – including everyone who dies and who is the killer.
story: Warning: This story contains spoilers for the end of "Thursday Murder Club."

In "Thursday Murder Club," a Netflix movie based on Richard Osman's novel of the same name, four residents in the Coopers Chase retirement home have a hobby of trying to solve cold cases. Then, they find themselves in the middle of an active investigation.

At the start of the film, they’re faced with two conundrums: A case from the 1970s in which a woman was stabbed and fell out of a window; and the fact that Ian, the man who owns the land the home is built on, is going through a nasty divorce and has to sell — no matter who he mows down in the process.

The members of the Club include Helen Mirren (as Elizabeth), Pierce Brosnan (as Ron), Ben Kingsley (as Ibrahim), Celia Imrie (as Joyce) and, from her bed in a coma, Susan Kirby as Penny, the former policewoman who helped her friends (now members) get old case logs to solve.

On top of that we’ve got familiar, most-welcome faces in Richard E. Grant (Bobby), David Tennant (Ian), Tom Ellis (Jason), and Jonathan Pryce (Stephen), all of whom turn up playing various dubious characters.
Naomi Ackie (Donna) is the policewoman who’s stuck serving tea to her co-workers until the Club tricks the force into putting her on Tony’s murder investigation.
Beyond the central mystery, there are side stories.

Elizabeth has a mysterious background (turns out she worked for MI6) and a beloved husband (Pryce) with dementia. Ron, a former union organizer, has a famous son whose star is fading. Ibrahim lives meticulously but never felt he fit in anywhere. Joyce’s hard-driving hedge fund daughter who turns out to be an unexpected ally. Elizabeth makes two newfound friends in Donna and Ian’s assistant Bogdan (Henry Lloyd-Hughes), one of which turns out to not be as much of a friend as she’d imagined.
Read on for a rundown of what happens.
Who Dies and Who Are the Killers in ‘Thursday Murder Club’?

The story really picks up when the murders start. Ian’s partner Tony (Geoff Bell) turns up dead after an argument with Ian — he won’t sell his portion of the property, since his dear aunt lives in the home. Then, Ian himself also keels over.

What might surprise viewers is to find out there’s a link among all of these players to the cold case the Club has been trying to solve — one that involves a long-missing third partner (and crime lord) in the home, who has full control over what happens to the home after Tony and Ian snuff it.
In the end, after a lot of tea and cake, fooling the police, Club trickery and a sudden buyer who turns up to purchase the property and save it, here’s whodunit for all four murders. Yep, all four.
Tony is done in by Bogdan, who swears he didn’t mean to do it. Bogdan is an illegal Polish worker in the UK and Tony wouldn’t give him back his passport.
The cold case's solution also relates to the residents of Coopers Chase.

Peter, Angela’s boyfriend at the time, killed his girlfriend. Early on we learn that he probably was guilty all along — but was considered “one of the boys” by the police at the time and allowed to disappear.

Well, not all of “the boys” agreed with that — Penny, who was low person at the station at the time, was sure Peter had killed Angela, and tired of seeing so many abusers get off, she killed him herself. Her husband John kept this a secret for decades.

When Ian decided to start digging up the church and gravesite ahead of selling off the land (and repurposing the home as an events location), John knew he’d find the bones of Mercer, which he and Penny had hidden in the graveyard.

He worried his wife would be implicated after all these years, and took out Ian with a needle full of fentanyl. Once John confesses, the rest of the Club leave him for a last moment with his comatose wife, knowing he will use another fentanyl needle to let her go to a peaceful rest (because once he’s jailed, he can’t be there for her).
Is Coopers Chase saved?

It almost certainly is! Elizabeth suggests that Joyce’s financially-focused daughter Joanna (Ingrid Oliver) should buy the place, an offer Joanna finds “intriguing.” And since Coopers Chase appears in Osman’s sequels, it’s safe to say this was only an attempted murder.
As of now, Netflix hasn’t confirmed that they plan to make movies of the rest of Osman’s books, but we already know we’re ready to return to the scenes of the crimes.

title: 'Love Island USA' Stars Iris and Pepe Confirm Their Break Up After Reunion
summary: “Love Island USA” stars Iris Kendall and Pepe Garcia-Gonzalez have broken up. The two shared that things did not work out after leaving the villa.
story: “Love Island USA” stars Iris Kendall and Pepe Garcia-Gonzalez have broken up.
Days after the Season 7 reunion aired, the couple confirmed that they are no longer together. The pair came in fourth place during the July 13 finale.

“I had hoped to keep this private, but I’m so grateful for all of the love and support I’ve received since leaving the villa, and I wanted to share an update,” Iris told E! News on Aug. 28. “The connection that I formed has ended, and while it isn’t how I would have imagined, I will always value the unique experience that we shared.”
She continued, “It’s been a difficult transition, but I’m moving forward with hope, gratitude, and positivity for the future.”
She also expressed her appreciation for fans of the show, saying, “Thank you for continuing to stand by me—your support means more than I can ever express.”
Iris' statement comes after Pepe also confirmed the split.
“We’re not together anymore, and that’s the way it goes,” he told TMZ on Aug. 28, explaining, “It’s a tough thing when there’s a lot of eyes on you 24/7.”
He added, “It’s stressful. Being in the limelight isn’t always the best thing in the world.”
After leaving the villa, the pair told TODAY.com about their future as a couple.

“I think at this point, everybody kind of knows we’re together, obviously. They know it’s very different than normal relationships,” Pepe said. “It’s just, continue to be with each other and focus on each other and just make sure that we can see this through.”
However, on Aug. 24, fans spotted that Iris and Pepe didn't follow each other on Instagram. During the reunion, which was taped on Aug. 12 and aired Aug. 25, they appeared to still be together.
Pepe said they had “conversations about what dating looks like” in the real world, yet Iris quipped, “You have to ask someone to be your girlfriend” to make it official.
When host Ariana Madix asked, “Do you want to be his girlfriend?”, Iris said yes, adding they were going in the right direction.
It appears things panned out differently.
The break up comes after “Love Island USA” Season 7 winners Amaya Espinal and Bryan Arenales also announced that they broke up.
The only couple in the top four still together are Nic Vansteenberghe and Olandria.

title: Jason Kelce Is at His Most Jason Kelce in Infomercial-Inspired Ad
summary: Jason Kelce, who recently dyed his beard dark black, stars in a new commercial for Garage Beer inspired by Billy Mays.
story: Jason Kelce dyed his beard dark black — so he could unleash his inner Billy Mays in a new beer commercial.
The retired Philadelphia Eagles star appears with the dark beard in a new ad released on Aug. 29 for Garage Beer, the craft beer company he co-owns with brother Travis Kelce.

In the new commercial, Kelce does his best impression of Mays, the legendary pitchman famous for his OxiClean infomercials. Mays, who died at 50 in 2009, was known for his jet-black beard, booming voice and enthusiasm for household products. (The commercial does include some swearing.)

"Are you tired of boring, watered-down brews that leave you feeling flat?" Kelce says in the commercial while wearing a blue Garage Beer shirt reminiscent of the shirt Mays wore while pitching OxiClean. "Sick of settling for the same old beers that just don't pack a punch?!"
He then goes on to give his best sales pitch for Garage Beer, saying its "light, crisp taste hits you like a V-8 engine!" He adds that it's "beer-flavored beer" that "won't break the bank."
“We’re living in a time where beer drinkers are craving more than commercials — they want characters, they want stories, and they want to laugh," Kelce said in a statement to TODAY.com.

Kelce had hinted at the reason for his new look when he said on the Aug. 27 episode of the "New Heights" podcast that he dyed his beard for a bit for Garage Beer. He foreshadowed that he would be doing his version of a Mays infomercial.
“I came out of the shower. Immediately I looked like Billy Mays,” Kelce joked on the podcast. “It was the most ridiculous-looking thing I had ever seen in my life.”
Kelce also referenced Mays in an Instagram video on Aug. 28 in which he showed the reactions of his wife, Kylie, and his former teammates to his dyed beard.
Eagles offensive lineman Lane Johnson sees Kelce's new look and immediately exclaims, "Billy Mays here with the power of OxiClean!"
"Full disclosure, Lane hit me with the Billy Mays line first," Kelce wrote in the caption.
Kylie Kelce also cracks up on FaceTime after seeing the dyed beard for the first time.
"I look like a panda," her husband says.
Kelce made it clear on "New Heights" that he will be letting his natural gray hairs grow back in his beard.
“I want to emphasize though ... I didn’t do it out of vanity, I did it for a bit. That’s all I’m saying," he said. "I think there’s a distinct difference.”

title: French Montana Announces Engagement to Dubai Princess Sheikha Mahra. See the $1.1M Ring
summary: French Montana and Sheikha Mahra Mohammed Rashed Al Maktoum, a princess of Dubai, are engaged
story: French Montana and Sheikha Mahra Mohammed Rashed Al Maktoum, a princess of Dubai, are engaged.

The “Unforgettable” rapper presented his wife-to-be with an engagement ring with an estimated value of $1.1 million, his representative confirmed to TODAY.com. The ring features an 11.53 carat emerald cut diamond and was custom-designed by celebrity jeweler Eric The Jeweler of Mavani & Co.
The couple confirmed their engagement Aug. 29 on Instagram by jointly sharing a close-up photo of the ring on Sheikha Mahra's hand. They captioned the post with emoji of a heart and stars.
The couple are “still working on their wedding plans” and are “looking forward to spending their lives together," French Montana's representative said in a statement.

Sheikha Mahra is the daughter of Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, the vice president and prime minister of the United Arab Emirates and ruler of Dubai, according to the rapper's representative. Her mother is the UAE leader's ex-wife Zoe Grigorakos, according to Harper’s Bazaar Arabia.

News of Sheikha Mahra's engagement comes a little more than a year after she made headlines after announcing her divorce from ex-husband Sheikh Mana bin Mohammed bin Rashid bin Mana Al Maktoum in a since-deleted post on Instagram, the BBC reported.

The princess reportedly shared a post in July 2024 that began, “Dear Husband,” and concluded, “I divorce you, I divorce you, and I divorce you,” an apparent use of an Islamic practice called "triple talaq." The practice allows a man to quickly divorce his wife by repeating the word “talaq,” or divorce, three times, the BBC reported.
The former couple wed in April 2023, and share one child, a daughter born in 2024, according to the BBC. In May, Sheikha Mahra celebrated her daughter's first birthday on Instagram.

French Montana, whose real name is Karim Kharbouch, was previously married to Deen Kharbouch, with whom he shares a son. The rapper was also romantically linked to Khloe Kardashian in 2014, per "E! News."

title: ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’ Releases Trailer for the Last 3 Episodes. Why Fans Say It’s ‘Uncharted Territory’
summary: With 3 episodes left in Season 3, "The Summer I Turned Pretty" is seemingly going off book as a new trailer teases Belly's adventures in Paris.
story: The last season of the Prime Video teen drama “The Summer I Turned Pretty” has now entered what some fans are calling “uncharted territory.”
While the television series has stayed relatively true to the books it is based on so far, fans noticed at the end of Season 3, Episode 8, that the show has largely run out of content to cover.
But, there are still three episodes left, which will air each Wednesday until the finale Sept. 17.

On Aug. 29, Prime Video released a trailer for the show's final act, giving viewers a sneak peek at what might be ahead after all of Season 3's drama and heartbreak so far. (Warning: Spoilers ahead for Season 3 of "The Summer I Turned Pretty.")
What Happens in the New Trailer for the Final Episodes of ‘The Summer I Turned Pretty’?
At the very end of the third season’s eighth episode, the show's main character, Belly (Lola Tung), spontaneously buys a ticket to Paris, the destination of her study abroad dreams.

Belly’s leap of faith came immediately after her engagement with Jeremiah (Gavin Casalegno) ended on their wedding day, following his accusation that she's still in love with his brother, Conrad (Christopher Briney). The episode ended with Belly ready to start a new adventure.
The trailer hints that the rest of the season will follow Belly on her journey in Paris.
With the song “Anything Can Happen” playing in the background, Belly is shown taking off her engagement ring on the plane, then jumping headfirst into her experience abroad.
“I don’t even know who I am anymore. I need to find the person that I can be,” Belly says in the a voiceover as she admires Paris monuments and makes new friends.

In various clips, she runs through Paris gardens, takes in the view of the Eiffel Tower and dances with some unfamiliar faces. The end of the trailer, however, teases that she hasn't fully left her old life behind: It's revealed that Conrad has sent her a letter, and Briney can be heard saying “Dear Belly" right before the trailer ends.
For many viewers, the mid-season trailer came as a surprise.
“Next time before you post a teaser, first tell us to take seat,” one user commented on X.
“UNCHARTED WATERS. I’ve got a pit in my stomach, especially after ‘Dear Belly,’” another fan added.
“Uncharted territory for us book readers. I’m stressed,” added another.
How Does the Book End?
(Warning: Spoilers ahead for "We'll Always Have Summer" by Jenny Han.)

The third season of "The Summer I Turned Pretty" has closely followed the events of the third book in the young adult series. "We'll Always Have Summer" ends with Jeremiah and Belly calling off their wedding, followed by a mere three-page epilogue — so going forward in the show, "anything can happen," as Prime Video notes.

In that epilogue, the story jumps forward "a couple of years later" to Belly reading the letter Susannah left for her wedding day. As she reflects on Susannah's message, Belly reveals that she is marrying Conrad.

She recaps that after the broken engagement with Jeremiah, she did study abroad — in Spain. During her time overseas, she had “lots and lots of adventures," Belly says in the epilogue. And like the trailer hints, Conrad re-connected with her by sending letters. While she didn’t write back at first, “they still came, once a month, every month.”
Then, she says when she saw him at her college graduation a year later, she “just knew" they were meant to be together.
The book ends with Belly and Conrad enjoying their happy ending. After their wedding, they run together into the water at Cousins Beach.
"This is our start. This is the moment it becomes real," Belly says in the last paragraph of the book.
What Do Conrad's Letters Say In the Book?
In some editions of "We'll Always Have Summer," Han includes bonus content, including some of the letters Conrad wrote to Belly while she was in Spain.
He starts his first letter by sending Belly her beloved polar bear stuffed animal, Junior Mint, which he won for her during one of their summers together in Cousins.
Throughout the letters, Conrad shares the latest news from home and brings up inside jokes, such as her obsession with Sour Patch Kids and their time spending Christmas together.
In one notable letter excerpt, he says Belly’s mom, Laurel, told him that Belly “met some Spanish guy named Benito, and he rides around on a scooter.”
Whether or not the show will include a new love interest for Belly is unclear. But, as some fans on Reddit note, it seems like the final episodes will have a lot of ground to cover.
“Wow, that ending with Conrad!" one fan wrote. "I almost wish we had a Season 4 now."

title: Where Is Kendra Licari From 'Unknown Number' Now?
summary: Two teens in Beal City, Michigan were receiving cruel and menacing texts.
story: Two teens in Beal City, Michigan were receiving cruel and menacing texts. The person sending them ended up shocking them — and the entire town.
"Unknown Number: The High School Catfish," a Netflix documentary out Aug. 29, revisits the case of Lauryn and Kendra Licari, and updates viewers on where they are now.

In April 2023, a Michigan mom named Kendra Licari was sentenced to a minimum of 19 months in prison after pleading guilty to two counts of stalking a minor, according to Isabella County sentencing documents obtained by TODAY.com.
The minor was her daughter, Lauryn Licari, who had been receiving cruel messages since September 2021, according to charges obtained by TODAY.com.
At Licari’s sentencing,  Judge Mark Duthie told the court that the “truly horrible” case had shown him the “worst in human nature,” per courtroom reporting from The Morning Sun newspaper.
“I can’t imagine any parent saying such horrible things to her own daughter,” he told Licari.
Did Licari admit to sending the messages?
Licari made a full confession when she was arrested, said Isabella County Prosecutor David Barberi, according to the Morning Sun.
She pleaded guilty in a March 2023 plea deal to two counts of stalking a minor, per the sentencing document seen by TODAY.com.
In exchange, Barberi dropped the three additional charges against her: one count of obstruction and two counts of using a computer to commit a crime, the publication reported the following month.

At Licari’s sentencing in April 2023, she reportedly cried when she told the judge she was sorry for the pain her actions caused her victims, according to the Morning Sun, including her daughter and a teen initially blamed for the messages.
Licari told Judge Mark Duthie that she would take back her actions if she could, and that she was “ashamed, remorseful and embarrassed,” reported the publication.

A defense attorney for Licari told the judge that the disgraced mom had begun counseling and was also taking parenting classes. The attorney also stated that a psychiatric examination had determined that Licari suffers from mental illness, the newspaper reported.
Judge Duthie told the court during the sentencing that the “truly horrible” case had shown him the “worst in human nature.”
“I can’t imagine any parent saying such horrible things to her own daughter,” the judge told Licari.
He added, “It’s the kind of case that makes me glad that at the end of my term, I’m retiring.”
Where is Kendra Licari now?
Kendra Licari was sentenced to a maximum of five years in prison, with a minimum sentence of one year and seven months, per a sentencing document reviewed by TODAY.com.
She was released on parole on Aug. 8, 2024, and will be supervised as a parolee until February 2026, according to her inmate record from the Michigan Department of Corrections.
According to public records, Kendra Licari is living in Michigan.
Kendra Licari and her daughter, Lauryn Licari, were both interviewed in "Unknown Number."
In the documentary, Kendra Licari says she is “very disappointed” in herself.
According to her plea deal, Kendra Licari is not able to see her daughter. In the doc, Lauryn Licari says she wants to see her mom “when the time is right.”

“I think I want to trust her now, but I don’t think I can,” Lauryn Licari says. “Now that she’s out, I just want her to get the help she needs so then when we see each other, it doesn’t go back to the old ways and how it was before.”
TODAY.com has reached out to Kendra Licari for comment and has not heard back by the time of publication.

title: Bad Bunny Opens Up About the ‘Emotional’ Song That Made His Mom Cry
summary: Bad Bunny reveals the emotional story behind his song “La Mudanza,” which brought his mother to tears.
story: Bad Bunny is sharing a song that hit an emotional chord for his mother.
During an interview with "NBC Nightly News" anchor Tom Llamas, the superstar, whose given name is Benito Antonio Martínez Ocasio, shared how his mom teared up while listening to “La Mudanza.”
When asked why the song made his mom, Lysaurie Ocasio, cry, the artist explained the personal connection.
“Because I’m just telling the story about how my parents meet each other, and how I came to this world,” Bad Bunny shared. “So it’s a very special story and it’s a very emotional song.”
"La Mudanza" is featured on Bad Bunny's sixth studio album, “Debí Tirar Más Fotos,” which translates to “I should’ve taken more photos,” and was released in January.
The deeply personal, genre-blending LP is a love letter to Puerto Rico and family, and quickly became a chart-topper.

“I always wanted to make a salsa album,” he said, adding that he always thought it would be a project he did when he was older “when I turn 40 or something like that.” “And when I started to work on this album it was organically, everything. Like, “DTMF” song, the way that we created that song, it was- all just happening at the moment, feelings, people that (were) in the studio. You know, ‘Come here, let’s sing together.’”
Adding to his spotlight on his beloved culture and heritage, Bad Bunny kicked off a 30-show residency in his native Puerto Rico.

“It’s the best experience that I ever had in my life, in my career,” he said. “It’s more than a show. It’s more than a concert. It’s the culture right there, people all love each other, singing together. It’s something magical.”
You can see more of Bad Bunny during his full interview sit-down with Willie Geist on this weekend’s "Sunday TODAY."

title: Liam Payne's Girlfriend Shares Tribute on What Would Have Been His 32nd Birthday
summary: Kate Cassidy, the girlfriend of Liam Payne, paid an emotional tribute to the late singer to honor what would have been his 32nd birthday.
story: Kate Cassidy, the girlfriend of Liam Payne, paid an emotional tribute to the late singer to honor what would have been his 32nd birthday.

Cassidy shared a carousel of pics of her and the former One Direction member Aug. 29 on Instagram. "My dearest Liam, It breaks my heart being that I can’t hand you a physical birthday card today. That I can’t hear your laugh, or tell you all the things I wish I’d said a thousand more times," she wrote in her caption.
Cassidy went on to say she had been, "struggling to find the right words" before wishing him a  happy birthday.

"Today you would have been 32. In your 31 years here on this earth you brought so much joy, happiness and hope to so many — especially to me. I hope you know how brightly you still shine, even from up there," she wrote.
“I would give up years of my life just to give you a few more,” Cassidy continued, adding that she missed “making memories” and “having things to look forward to" with Payne.

"But today, my birthday gift to you is my strength. I promise you I will celebrate you extra today, honor your life, and cherish the beautiful times we’ve had. August 29th will be a date that sits in my heart for the rest of my life. I love you so much," she concluded.
Payne died in October 2024 after falling from a balcony on the third floor of a hotel in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
Prior to his tragic death, Payne filmed his final television appearance for the new Netflix singing competition “Building the Band."
The show, which premiered on July 9 and is hosted by former Backstreet Boy AJ McLean, features Payne serving as a judge Payne alongside Nicole Scherzinger and Kelly Rowland.
Speaking to TODAY.com in July, McLean remembered Payne as “the coolest dude."

“Whether it was a dressing room, on set, where he was, he lit up that space with his energy, with his open heart, open mind. He was extremely, very well spoken, very articulate when it came to giving feedback as a mentor to these groups," McLean said of his fellow former boy bander.
During a "Sunday Sitdown" with Willie Geist the same month,  Scherzinger said Payne was a "dear friend" to her.

“I put One Direction together, so it’s come full circle for us,” said the Tony winner, referring to her role in the formation of the popular boy band, which counted Payne, Harry Styles, Zayn Malik, Niall Horan and Louis Tomlinson as its members, during her time as a judge on “The X Factor.”
"Building the Band" was a "full circle" moment for Payne, who was able to give the show's aspiring artists "really good advice, thanks to his own success, said Scherzinger.
"Liam just shines in the show,” she said. “He’s just a natural beautiful bright light. Anyone who knows him — he has a very kind, giving heart. And he gets to, you know, give back.”

title: Queen Latifah's Lookalike Son Rebel Makes Rare Appearance With Mom at WNBA Game
summary: Queen Latifah made a rare appearance with her young son, Rebel, at a New York Liberty basketball game in Brooklyn, New York.
story: Queen Latifah made a rare appearance with her young son, Rebel.
On Aug. 25, the pair stepped out in Brooklyn, New York, to see the Connecticut Sun take on the New York Liberty at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York.
On the court, Queen Latifah and her kid were seen posing for pictures next to players, including Olivia Nelson-Ododa, Aaliyah Edwards and Bria Hartley from the Connecticut Sun.
They were also seen taking a picture with New York Liberty player Jonquel Jones.
For the special outing, Rebel wore an aqua and black colored jersey with a pair of cargo pants and Laitfah donned what appeared to be a silk shirt with some blue jeans, white sneakers and a hat.

The "Living Single" star is a proud mom of one and she shares Rebel with her partner, Eboni Nichols. In 2021, she gave her kiddo a shout-out when she was being honored with the lifetime achievement award at the 2021 BET Awards.

During her closing remarks, she said, "I’m going to get off this stage, but I thank you so much for all of you, the fans for supporting every crazy-a-- thing I’ve done through the years. And thank you for making 'Equalizer' No. 1. Eboni, my love. Rebel, my love. Peace — Happy Pride!”
In 2017, Queen Latifah spoke to People about parenthood and said she always envisioned her with a "big family."

"I’m a late bloomer. I’m a late bloomer with a lot of things and you know — nobody’s perfect. I’m an overachiever in some ways and just like slow as molasses in other ways," she said. "I think I kind of needed to grow and mature and get everything kind of taken care of with everything before I was able to really deal with it."
The "U.N.I.T.Y." rapper also opened up about adoption and said that's always something that's caught her eye.
"I definitely want to adopt," she said.
Queen Latifah added that it didn't matter how old the child was -- she just wanted to be there to give them a sense of family.

"To me, it's the most unselfish thing you could do, to be a parent. It's not about you at all. It's about what you can give to support this child growing into adulthood. And so it doesn't matter if it's a baby or a toddler or a teenager, for that matter," she said. "As long as they get to feel like they have a mother, they have a home, they have a family and somebody who's there for them."

title: ‘Hunting Wives’ Creator Rebecca Cutter Reacts to ‘Great’ Fan Theory About Margo, Sophie and Murder
summary: "The Hunting Wives" showrunner Rebecca Cutter talks to TODAY.com about the Netflix show's Margo (Malin Akerman) and Sophie (Brittany Snow) romance and foreshadowing.
story: Warning: This story contains spoilers from “The Hunting Wives” book and television series.

You won’t find a bigger fan of “The Hunting Wives” than its creator, Rebecca Cutter. The self-professed “Margo truther” is basking in “incredible gratitude” after such massive fan reaction to the Netflix hit, which continues to be the most-watched streaming original show this month.

The series, originally made for Starz before finding its home at Netflix, has been a mainstay in the streamer’s Top 10 list in the U.S. since its July release. It has become the subject of multiple group chats and fan edits on social media, and a new ship has set sail as a result of the eight-episode season: Margo (Malin Åkerman) and Sophie (Brittany Snow). The Instagram account for “The Hunting Wives” even posted a callout for viewers to cast their vote for what their couple name should be.
“I had a lot of confidence in what the show was,” Cutter tells TODAY.com, adding if Netflix could bring in the viewership, “I know I can keep them watching the show.”
“I started to let myself be hopeful,” she continues, “but I still could have never predicted the wide range of people that seem to love the show. That’s shocking to me.”

“The Hunting Wives,” which is an adaptation of author May Cobb’s novel, follows Sophie O’Neil and her husband, Graham O’Neil (Evan Jonigkeit), as they move with their son from the Northeast to a small town in east Texas. She falls in with a group of Southern female socialites, which includes queen bee Margo Banks, who happens to be married to Graham’s hotshot new boss, Jed Banks (Dermot Mulroney), an aspiring politician. The group’s idea of a good time includes going boar hunting, a lot of drinking and for some, even hooking up with one another. It doesn’t take long for Sophie to fall under Margo’s spell, and the two meet up for secret romantic rendezvouses. At the same time, they’re grappling with the latest drama to hit the small town: the murder of teenager Abby Jackson.

In twists that deviate from the book, Margo ends up being Abby’s killer — not Jill (Katie Lowes), one of the moms in the girls group whose 18-year-old son, Brad, is also secretly hooking up with Margo. And, Margo does not die in the TV adaptation, but she does at the end of the book.
Cutter says she knew “well before” Åkerman was cast as Margo that she wanted Margo as the killer in the show.
“That was one of the first things when I read the book that I knew would be one of the big changes,” she explains. “I knew I wanted her to do it, and I knew I wanted her to stay alive.”

She also crafted a grittier personal backstory for her Margo, which includes a complicated relationship with brother Kyle. Cutter says her “main intention” with the changes she made was to “give everybody more sort of character work to do.”

“I also just wanted to open up a different part of Texas,” Cutter says. “It is fun to watch rich people, but it’s also interesting to open up a different world and to have a real divide of the classes.”
She adds that she loves the scene of Sophie showing up at a trailer park to visit a naked Kyle during his “meth bender.”
“It opens up the world and opens up plot possibilities,” she says.
After reading the book, Cutter traveled to Longview, Texas, about two hours east of Dallas, to do research, and not only met Cobb, but Cobb's high school best friend.
“Within 10 minutes, it was totally the ‘I love you’ scene (in the show with Margo and Sophie),” she says.
She says they went on a three-day trip and shot guns, ate barbecue and went to honky-tonks.
“It was just a blast, and we talk, like, three times a week now,” Cutter says.
Cobb previously told TODAY.com she feels that Cutter “took the spirit of the book, of these rowdy, sassy — to put it mildly — Texas women, and just turned it up to an 11.”
She added that Cutter made the show “even more unapologetic and juicy and bonkers than the book.”

“Really blowing out the different storylines and adding in some new characters and giving existing characters different backstories,” Cobb said. “It's escapist fun at a time when I feel like people are really looking for that.”
About That Margo, Sophie, Abby Fan Theory

When Margo and Sophie first meet at an NRA party at Margo and Jed's house, Sophie offers Margo a Xanax. Later on, Sophie and Margo again take Sophie's Xanax before embarking on a blackout bender the night Abby is murdered.
Cutter says she didn’t really think of the Xanax connection as an Easter egg but more of a plot device for the blackout and to “very specifically” establish Sophie’s state of mind.
“I try and always be as character-motivated as possible and not so much for foreshadowing, but I’m glad it worked out,” she says.

What could possibly be foreshadowing, however, is the boar hunting outing that the wives embark on. Sophie, new to shooting, takes down a boar — but doesn’t kill it. Callie (Jaime Ray Newman), who also happens to be the sheriff’s wife, delivers the fatal shot to put the boar out of its misery.

As the series progresses, Sophie becomes the prime suspect in Abby’s murder because her gun is the one used to kill Abby, and surveillance footage in the woods shows Abby and Sophie interacting the night Abby was killed. The show actually begins with a scene of a wounded woman, who viewers later learn is Abby, running in the woods shouting for help while she's being shot at. Sophie can’t remember the events of the night because she was blacked out. After various other clues arise in the case, police presume Jill is the killer, and Sophie is seemingly free.
Sophie, however, pieces together that Margo is actually the killer and confronts her friend turned lover, who begs her not to tell, saying she loves her and “fixed it.”

One fan theory states that Sophie actually fired the initial shots at Abby, but she didn’t kill her — just like the boar — and Margo stepped in to deliver the kill shot to protect both Sophie and herself. Margo just never told Sophie about those initial shots, possibly to protect Sophie, who expressed guilt to Margo over a previous accident in the Northeast when she hit and killed a pedestrian while drinking and driving, according to the fan theory.
“It’s a great theory,” Cutter says. “I don’t want to confirm or deny because who knows what will come out in future seasons.”
The Margo and Sophie of It All
Before Sophie, Margo was in a secret romantic relationship on the side with Callie. But once Sophie comes to town, she becomes her focus, and Margo dumps Callie.
Margo tells Sophie, “There’s something about me that wants to protect you,” and by contrast, later says to Callie, “I’m Margo f------ Banks. I don’t need protection.”
Was this moment with Sophie a genuine one for Margo, and she was actually looking out for someone who wasn’t herself?

“I always feel like with Margo — and actually I feel this way about humans in general — this is how I like to write characters. Everything can be both things at once,” Cutter says. “You can be a manipulator but also mean it. So I do think she feels that way about Sophie, and I think that’s one of the beautiful things about Brittany Snow’s performance, is that everyone, I think, kind of feels like, ‘I wish I could just wrap this girl up in a blanket because she’s causing herself a lot of trouble.’
“And I think Margo definitely feels protective of her and loving of her, and it doesn’t mean that it’s all out of the goodness of her heart either. She obviously had ulterior motives.”
Cutter adds she believes the “richest characters” are “sort of femme fatale.”
“It’s not fun if they’re just completely calculated monsters, but it’s not fun if they don’t have any evil intent, either,” she explains. “There should always be multiple layers going on.”
Cobb said the Margo-Sophie dynamic in the show is similar to the book with “Sophie falling under her spell.”

“I do think Margo has feelings for her, but Margo is a more transactional person and manipulator,” she said. “I think she genuinely cares for Sophie, but, you know, watch out if, oh, I just can't wait. I hope there's a Season 2 so we can find out what's going to happen.” (The show has not yet been officially picked up for Season 2.)
There are, of course, Margo and Sophie fans who want the pairing to be the endgame, while others don’t think they’d make it in the long run because Margo can be so toxic and self-serving.

“I just love Margo even — I love her either way,” Cutter says. “I’m, like, a Margo truther. I don’t care if she’s evil. I don’t care if she was completely justified. I like her. I’m going to watch her either way. I’m going to sleep with her.

“It’s funny, people want to really have it defined, and they want to have it defined by me. And I always say, like, ‘Babe, make your own decision. I don’t own the character. If you want to think that she’s telling the truth, believe that. If you don’t, it should work either way.’”

(For the record, Cutter is a fan of the first wig Margo wears in the show, before going blond as Jed’s campaign for governor gets underway. “I’m shocked that everyone hates it so much. I think she’s iconic. … It looks fantastic on her and established her character.”)
Her Favorite Margo and Sophie Scene

Cutter says the Margo and Sophie scene she loves the most is from the first episode, when Margo brings Sophie home following an intimate detour in a parking lot after a night out at the bar with the girls.

“I love the moment when Margo’s dropping her off in that first episode, and she’s like, ‘Oh, we’re going to have so much fun together. I love you.’ And Sophie goes, ‘I love you, too.’ It was exactly how I pictured it when I wrote it, which is that thing of … women do this all the time. We make fast friends, and we say, ‘I love you,’ not meaning it, exactly. … But then Sophie saying it in a different way. Obviously, she’s not in love with her yet, but Brittany is putting all those levels into it where you’re like, ‘Wait, does she love her love her?’ She’s not just saying it back in the same tone that Margo was saying it. That’s for sure.”
Cutter says she’s seen the episode “hundreds of times in the editing room.”
“Erwin Stoff, who’s the other executive producer, every time he knew that it would make me smile,” she says of the scene. “So he would always look over and wait for me to be smiling at that take.”
Is Sophie in Love With Margo?
Snow said she played the character of Sophie like she was in love with Margo.
“I don’t like to speak for our fictional characters, even though I did write them,” Cutter says. “I certainly think she was falling in love with her.”
While the reveal of Margo as Abby’s murderer “complicates things,” Cutter says, “It becomes a question of, like, ‘Can you love someone knowing how deeply flawed they are?’”
That’s something that will have to be addressed in the future, as will the fallout of Sophie killing Margo’s brother in the show’s final moments of the first season.
Will Margo ever be able to forgive Sophie? “We’ll have to see,” Cutter teases.

One thing that is for certain is that Sophie has “been in denial” about her sexuality. A flashback reveals Sophie and her female college roommate crossed the friendship line and spent a romantic night together.

“I think that was important to me to show that it wasn’t just — Margo is magical, even though she is, but, like, I mean she’s magical to bring her out of it, but I did want to give Sophie more of a thorough queerness … a richer sense that it isn’t just, ‘Oh, Margo’s this unicorn,’ but that this is something Sophie has thought and felt before and been in denial about or pushing away. And that Margo is the one that’s able to make it seem like a feasible life choice.”
Cobb said it was “super smart” for Cutter to give Sophie “a more compelling background.”
“She's falling head over heels for Margo,” Cobb said of Sophie, “and it's an unstoppable force.”

“In the book, she doesn't have that backstory, and then Graham's need to sort of control her,” she continued. “I think there's a tension there of, ‘Wow, there's absolutely nothing wrong with my home life. Husband's great, treats me great. And yet I cannot resist the siren call of Margo Banks.’”
The show has led many people to share their thoughts online about how the show has made them rethink sexuality.
Cutter says it’s “so rewarding” to see her work be that “closely watched and processed.”

“You spend all this time writing something, and you don’t know — people could just be there texting or doing their laundry or yelling at their kids and barely watching it,” she says. “So to have people, like, making edits and really parsing out, like, ‘What did that line mean?’ or ‘What was that look?’ or ‘Look at what her hand does there.’
“It’s just like, oh my God, you feel so seen. And I’m so grateful that people are feeling seen by this show. I love that it’s a two-way street.”

title: Does Jackie Choose Cole or Alex in 'My Life With the Walter Boys' Season 2?
summary: Does Jackie Howard end up with Cole or Alex at the end of My LIfe with the Walter Boys Season 2?
story: Jackie Howard’s love life ended on a cliffhanger at the end of Season 1 of “My Life with the Walter Boys.”

The Netflix series follows a Manhattan teen who moves to Colorado after losing her family. She now lives with her late mom’s best friend and her many (many) kids — eight, plus two cousins living with the family.

Jackie has a “thing” with two of the Walter boys: Younger brother Alex (Ashby Gentry) and older brother Cole (Noah Lalonde). She dates Alex in Season 1 — then kisses Cole in the finale. It’s enough to send her running away for the summer back to New York.
Come Season 2, Jackie tells Alex that she and Cole had kissed. He's livid and confronts his brother, who tries to apologize. Alex doesn't accept the apology.

But it doesn't take long for Alex to decide that he can't get over Jackie and, despite some other flirtations, they get back together. Still, Cole and Jackie share a few longing glances, indicating things aren't quite over between them.

“This season, Jackie’s ready to face everything a little bit more head on. Season 1, she pushes everything away and runs away from her problems. And I think Season 2, she’s trying not to do that,” Nikki Rodriguez, who plays Jackie, tells TODAY.com.
Read on to find out how things end up between Jackie and the Walter boys.
Who does Jackie end up with in the end of ‘My Life with the Walter Boys’ Season 2?
Season 2 ends with Jackie at a crossroads between both Cole and Alex, and possibly about to lose them both.
Earlier on in the episode, Cole stumbles on Alex and Jackie kissing and seems upset. He confronts Jackie about getting back together with Alex.
“I was giving you space, like you asked. But I thought we had something. So I’ve been wracking my brain trying to figure out why you’d be with my brother — again,” Cole says.
“We said that we were going to be friends,” Jackie says.
“We’ve never just been friends,” Cole says.
Jackie says she “can’t be” with someone who makes her feel the way Cole does. It’s then that Cole declares he loves Jackie. She admits she loves him too.
“Why would being with me be so awful?” he asks.
She indicates it has something to do with her history and the trauma of losing her family. Cole makes her feel out of control _ and she can't have that.
“When we kissed, it was the only time I ever stopped thinking about everything … I felt very free, like I was out of control. And I can’t have that. I can’t lose control,” she says.
Then — surprise, surprise — Alex reveals that he’s heard the entire conversation.
What do the actors think will come next?
Speaking to TODAY.com, Rodriguez addressed the question of “Cole or Alex” head-on.
“I get this question a lot, and I always say ‘Team Jackie.’ I mean it — I think that I think Jackie should follow her heart wherever that leads her to,” she says.

Rodriguez says Jackie is afraid to make a decision. “Jackie ultimately doesn’t want to hurt anybody, and she doesn’t want to make any mistakes. She tries to be this perfect version of herself all the time,” she says.
Meanwhile, after a season with Jackie, Noah Lalonde says Cole has made a decision about Jackie.

“When Jackie enters Cole’s life, he’s in a vulnerable position. Then here comes Jackie, having just lost her family and having somehow gotten back up. She serves as an inspiration to him … and as that develops, I think he realizes that she’s just the type of person you’d want to spend your life with,” Lalonde says.

Alex, meanwhile, is experiencing deja vu — he has been in this position before. In Season 1, we learn that Cole had hooked up with a girl Alex was seeing. Cole later says he didn’t know her connection to his brother.
When asked for his reaction to the declaration of love, Gentry says, “He’s probably thinking, ‘Bruh, again?’ I think he is just confused. So hopefully he’ll get some answers.”
Read a full recap of "My Life with the Walter Boys" Season 2's ending.

title: Car rides and hand-holding: Putin, Modi and Xi send Trump a pointed message
summary: TIANJIN, China — A private car ride with Vladimir Putin may not be as special as President Donald Trump thought
story: TIANJIN, China — A private car ride with Vladimir Putin may not be as special as President Donald Trump thought.

With a backseat bromance of their own, as well as hand-holding and hugs, the Russian leader, his Indian counterpart, Narendra Modi, and their host, Chinese leader Xi Jinping, put on a display Monday that seemed designed to turn heads in Washington.

The three leaders staked out long-held positions in comments at this key regional summit in the Chinese port city of Tianjin, but the tenor and the timing of the trio's embrace was impossible to ignore.

India, long courted by the West as a crucial Asian partner and counterweight to China, has been rattled by Trump’s tariffs; the Kremlin has publicly brushed aside Washington's peace push in Ukraine; and Beijing continues to spar with the U.S. over trade, Taiwan and global influence.
Amid this thicket of tensions, the cozy optics at the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) gathering appeared a clear signal in the face of U.S. pressure.

Weeks after Trump and Putin made headlines with a protocol-busting ride in “The Beast” at their Alaska summit, Modi joined the Russian leader for a drive in the back of Putin's own armored limo — a not-so-subtle statement of defiance just days after the U.S. doubled tariffs on India to 50% as punishment for buying Russian oil.
Russian state media reporter Pavel Zarubin said the pair spent nearly an hour in the car before proceeding to bilateral talks.
“I always feel that meeting you has been a memorable experience,” Modi said to Putin later during the talks.
The Russian leader called Modi his "dear friend," espousing Russia and India's "friendly and trusting" relations.

In a speech to delegates, Putin did say that “understandings” reached at his summit with Trump could form the basis for peace in Ukraine, but he gave little indication of a shift in his position and issued his customary rebuke blaming the West’s “constant attempts to drag Ukraine into NATO” for causing the war.
'A totally one sided disaster!'

Perhaps watching from Washington, Trump said Monday that the relationship between India and the U.S. had been “a totally one sided disaster!” and chided New Delhi for buying “most of its oil and military products from Russia,” and “very little from the U.S.”
He said that India had now offered to cut their tariffs on U.S. goods to zero. "But it's getting late," Trump added.
Whether the theatrics in Tianjin were spontaneous or carefully planned, “the message remains the same,” Keir Giles, a senior fellow at London-based think tank Chatham House, told NBC News.

“The close relationship that Trump sought with Putin is now on display between Putin and others,” he said, adding that the U.S. had "given India a real cause to look for friendship and partnership elsewhere."
That friction had also given India a reason to “mend fences” with China, said Alyssa Ayres, a senior fellow for India, Pakistan, and South Asia at the Council on Foreign Relations.
India has "lots of problems," with China, she said, "but it is right on their border, and it’s their largest trading partner in goods."
Xi, for his part, criticized the “bullying behavior” from unnamed countries, a veiled reference to the U.S.

He outlined his longstanding ambition to challenge the U.S.-led global economic and security order. “We must continue to take a clear stand against hegemonism and power politics, and practice true multilateralism,” he said, while laying out a new “Global Governance Initiative” that was short on concrete policies.
Talking in Tianjin
Much of this northeastern port city was on lockdown ahead of the summit, the biggest since the SCO’s founding in 2002.

China welcomed dozens of leaders from Eurasian member states and other partner and observer countries for talks on trade, energy cooperation and regional stability. Their motorcades brought car and pedestrian traffic to a halt, with the area around the sprawling event venue on lockdown and security stepped up at the city’s train station.

Security barriers and police-manned checkpoints were present throughout Tianjin, with authorities' usual caution exacerbated by a spectacular military parade set to take place Wednesday in nearby Beijing.

Focus on the growing summit, part of China’s long-running effort to challenge U.S. dominance, has only been amplified this year by global upheaval from Trump-era policies and other foreign policy shifts.
India and China have long sparred over their Himalayan border, trade tensions and Beijing’s support for India’s rival, Pakistan.
But shared grievances — including Trump’s tariffs, which in China’s case have reached as high as 145% — have helped carve out common ground.
Against that backdrop, Modi’s first visit to China in seven years and his apparent camaraderie with Xi and Putin appeared especially striking.
While Modi joyously clasped Trump’s hand during a massive rally in Texas in 2019, Indian media on Monday seized on his friendship with Putin as a message of defiance against the U.S.
Indian television channel Republic World called it a “big diplomatic win” for India, while a headline on new channel Aaj Tak ran “Trump’s dictator vs. Modi-Putin’s friendship.”

In the wake of the Tianjin summit, the U.S. embassy in India highlighted that the partnership between the two nations “continues to reach new heights,” spanning “innovation and entrepreneurship, defense, and broader bilateral ties.”
But the message, from Modi as well as Xi and Putin, seemed clear: They may have differences but they are ready to stand — or sit — together.
Janis Mackey Frayer reported from Tianjin, and Freddie Clayton from London.

title: At least 800 killed as powerful earthquake rocks Afghanistan
summary: At least 800 people have been killed and over 1,000 have been injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.
story: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — At least 800 people have been killed and more than 1,300 others injured in Afghanistan after a 6.0-magnitude earthquake hit the country, Taliban officials said Monday.
The earthquake struck 17 miles from the eastern city of Jalalabad, near the border with Pakistan, at around midnight local time (3:30 p.m. ET Sunday), according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

Because the earthquake hit a remote mountainous area, “it will take time to get the exact information about human losses and damage to the infrastructure,” said Sharafat Zaman, a spokesperson for the Afghan Public Health Ministry.
